articles.headline: Sirius XM Prepares for Possible Bankruptcy
articles.snippet: The filing could put pressure on satellite company EchoStar, which owns a substantial amount of the company’s debt.
articles.abstract: The filing could put pressure on satellite company EchoStar, which owns a substantial amount of the company’s debt.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last summer, Mel Karmazin was rattling off his trademark one-liners to talk up the future of Sirius XM Radio, the combined company he ran that had just been blessed by regulators.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Zachery Kouwe

articles.headline: On Trail of War Criminals, NBC News Is Criticized
articles.snippet: Authorities are worried that a show probing human rights abuses might undercut official investigations.
articles.abstract: Authorities are worried that a show probing human rights abuses might undercut official investigations.
articles.lead_paragraph: NBC News, which teamed up with local police officers to trap sex offenders for its successful but scandalous “To Catch a Predator” series, is now using similar tactics to hunt bigger game: war criminals.

articles.headline: Washington Hopes ‘Vulture’ Investors Will Buy Bad Assets
articles.snippet: The White House wants to entice financiers to take risks on troubled assets, but the investors are wary.
articles.abstract: The White House wants to entice financiers to take risks on troubled assets, but the investors are wary.
articles.lead_paragraph: Howard S. Marks is the sort of financier who Washington hopes will help fix the nation’s tumbledown banks. Trouble is, he is not quite sure he wants the job.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Zachery Kouwe

articles.headline: For Geithner’s Debut, a Lukewarm Reception
articles.snippet: From his speech delivery style, to the markets’ reception of his announcements, to pundit commentaries on television, Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner did not receive great reviews.
articles.abstract: From his speech delivery style, to the markets’ reception of his announcements, to pundit commentaries on television, Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner did not receive great reviews.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner as much as for the troubled government program to bail out the financial system, Tuesday amounted to a do-over.

articles.headline: A Birth Control Pill That Promised Too Much
articles.snippet: As part of a settlement, Bayer is running ads that clarify the side benefits of its birth control drug, Yaz. Regulators say earlier ads played down the risks.
articles.abstract: As part of a settlement, Bayer is running ads that clarify the side benefits of its birth control drug, Yaz. Regulators say earlier ads played down the risks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bayer HealthCare Pharmaceuticals has just introduced a new $20 million advertising campaign for Yaz, the most popular birth control pill in the United States.

articles.headline: To Spend or to Save? Trick Question
articles.snippet: There are a few ways that American consumers can spend to help both their own finances and the country’s.
articles.abstract: There are a few ways that American consumers can spend to help both their own finances and the country’s.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s your fault. Part of it is, anyway. You, the American consumer, spent too much money. You bought too much house, took on too much debt and generally lived beyond your means. Your free-spending ways helped cause the worst financial crisis since the Great Depression.

articles.headline: 20 Dead as Taliban Attackers Storm Kabul Offices
articles.snippet: The attacks underscored the deteriorating security in Afghanistan on the eve of a visit by the U.S. envoy.
articles.abstract: The attacks underscored the deteriorating security in Afghanistan on the eve of a visit by the U.S. envoy.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was reported by Richard A. Oppel Jr., Abdul Waheed Wafa and Sangar Rahimi and written by Mr. Oppel.
articles.byline: By Richard A. Oppel Jr., Abdul Waheed Wafa and Sangar Rahimi

articles.headline: Nearly 700 at Merrill in Million-Dollar Club
articles.snippet: Bonuses of more than $1 million apiece went out to 696 people last year, New York’s attorney general said.
articles.abstract: Bonuses of more than $1 million apiece went out to 696 people last year, New York’s attorney general said.
articles.lead_paragraph: For nearly 700 lucky Merrill Lynch employees, 2008 was a million-dollar year, even though the brokerage firm lost $27 billion.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Louise Story
